--   information for table definition, column definition, and table and
--   column changes in the Kinesis message output. The default is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:noHexPrefix:KinesisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>kinesisSettings_noHexPrefix</a> - Set this optional parameter to
--   <tt>true</tt> to avoid adding a '0x' prefix to raw data in hexadecimal
--   format. For example, by default, DMS adds a '0x' prefix to the LOB
--   column type in hexadecimal format moving from an Oracle source to an
--   Amazon Kinesis target. Use the <tt>NoHexPrefix</tt> endpoint setting
--   to enable migration of RAW data type columns without adding the '0x'
--   prefix.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includePartitionValue:KinesisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>kinesisSettings_includePartitionValue</a> - Shows the partition
--   value within the Kinesis message output, unless the partition type is
--   <tt>schema-table-type</tt>. The default is <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:messageFormat:KinesisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>kinesisSettings_messageFormat</a> - The output format for the
--   records created on the endpoint. The message format is <tt>JSON</tt>
--   (default) or <tt>JSON_UNFORMATTED</tt> (a single line with no tab).
--   
--   <a>$sel:includeNullAndEmpty:KinesisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>kinesisSettings_includeNullAndEmpty</a> - Include NULL and empty
--   columns for records migrated to the endpoint. The default is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
newKinesisSettings :: KinesisSettings

-- | Provides information that defines a Microsoft SQL Server endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newMicrosoftSQLServerSettings</a> smart constructor.
data MicrosoftSQLServerSettings
MicrosoftSQLServerSettings' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe SafeguardPolicy -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> MicrosoftSQLServerSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>MicrosoftSQLServerSettings</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:bcpPacketSize:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_bcpPacketSize</a> - The maximum size of
--   the packets (in bytes) used to transfer data using BCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useBcpFullLoad:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_useBcpFullLoad</a> - Use this to
--   attribute to transfer data for full-load operations using BCP. When
--   the target table contains an identity column that does not exist in
--   the source table, you must disable the use BCP for loading table
--   option.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_serverName</a> - Fully qualified domain
--   name of the endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:querySingleAlwaysOnNode:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_querySingleAlwaysOnNode</a> - Cleans and
--   recreates table metadata information on the replication instance when
--   a mismatch occurs. An example is a situation where running an alter
--   DDL statement on a table might result in different information about
--   the table cached in the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The
--   full Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as
--   the trusted entity and grants the required permissions to access the
--   value in <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the SQL Server endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_username</a> - Endpoint connection user
--   name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:safeguardPolicy:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_safeguardPolicy</a> - Use this attribute
--   to minimize the need to access the backup log and enable DMS to
--   prevent truncation using one of the following two methods.
--   
--   <i>Start transactions in the database:</i> This is the default method.
--   When this method is used, DMS prevents TLOG truncation by mimicking a
--   transaction in the database. As long as such a transaction is open,
--   changes that appear after the transaction started aren't truncated. If
--   you need Microsoft Replication to be enabled in your database, then
--   you must choose this method.
--   
--   <i>Exclusively use sp_repldone within a single task</i>: When this
--   method is used, DMS reads the changes and then uses sp_repldone to
--   mark the TLOG transactions as ready for truncation. Although this
--   method doesn't involve any transactional activities, it can only be
--   used when Microsoft Replication isn't running. Also, when using this
--   method, only one DMS task can access the database at any given time.
--   Therefore, if you need to run parallel DMS tasks against the same
--   database, use the default method.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_password</a> - Endpoint connection
--   password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_databaseName</a> - Database name for the
--   endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full
--   ARN, partial ARN, or friendly name of the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> that contains the SQL Server endpoint
--   connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:readBackupOnly:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_readBackupOnly</a> - When this attribute
--   is set to <tt>Y</tt>, DMS only reads changes from transaction log
--   backups and doesn't read from the active transaction log file during
--   ongoing replication. Setting this parameter to <tt>Y</tt> enables you
--   to control active transaction log file growth during full load and
--   ongoing replication tasks. However, it can add some source latency to
--   ongoing replication.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useThirdPartyBackupDevice:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_useThirdPartyBackupDevice</a> - When
--   this attribute is set to <tt>Y</tt>, DMS processes third-party
--   transaction log backups if they are created in native format.
--   
--   <a>$sel:controlTablesFileGroup:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_controlTablesFileGroup</a> - Specifies a
--   file group for the DMS internal tables. When the replication task
--   starts, all the internal DMS control tables (awsdms_ apply_exception,
--   awsdms_apply, awsdms_changes) are created for the specified file
--   group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:MicrosoftSQLServerSettings'</a>,
--   <a>microsoftSQLServerSettings_port</a> - Endpoint TCP port.
newMicrosoftSQLServerSettings :: MicrosoftSQLServerSettings

-- | Provides information that defines a MongoDB endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newMongoDbSettings</a> smart constructor.
data MongoDbSettings
MongoDbSettings' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AuthMechanismValue -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe NestingLevelValue -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe AuthTypeValue -> Maybe Int -> MongoDbSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>MongoDbSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_serverName</a> - The name of the server on the
--   MongoDB source endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The full Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the trusted
--   entity and grants the required permissions to access the value in
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the MongoDB endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authMechanism:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_authMechanism</a> - The authentication mechanism
--   you use to access the MongoDB source endpoint.
--   
--   For the default value, in MongoDB version 2.x, <tt>"default"</tt> is
--   <tt>"mongodb_cr"</tt>. For MongoDB version 3.x or later,
--   <tt>"default"</tt> is <tt>"scram_sha_1"</tt>. This setting isn't used
--   when <tt>AuthType</tt> is set to <tt>"no"</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:MongoDbSettings'</a>, <a>mongoDbSettings_username</a>
--   - The user name you use to access the MongoDB source endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:kmsKeyId:MongoDbSettings'</a>, <a>mongoDbSettings_kmsKeyId</a>
--   - The KMS key identifier that is used to encrypt the content on the
--   replication instance. If you don't specify a value for the
--   <tt>KmsKeyId</tt> parameter, then DMS uses your default encryption
--   key. KMS creates the default encryption key for your Amazon Web
--   Services account. Your Amazon Web Services account has a different
--   default encryption key for each Amazon Web Services Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:MongoDbSettings'</a>, <a>mongoDbSettings_password</a>
--   - The password for the user account you use to access the MongoDB
--   source endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:nestingLevel:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_nestingLevel</a> - Specifies either document or
--   table mode.
--   
--   Default value is <tt>"none"</tt>. Specify <tt>"none"</tt> to use
--   document mode. Specify <tt>"one"</tt> to use table mode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_databaseName</a> - The database name on the MongoDB
--   source endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:docsToInvestigate:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_docsToInvestigate</a> - Indicates the number of
--   documents to preview to determine the document organization. Use this
--   setting when <tt>NestingLevel</tt> is set to <tt>"one"</tt>.
--   
--   Must be a positive value greater than <tt>0</tt>. Default value is
--   <tt>1000</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authSource:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_authSource</a> - The MongoDB database name. This
--   setting isn't used when <tt>AuthType</tt> is set to <tt>"no"</tt>.
--   
--   The default is <tt>"admin"</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full ARN, partial
--   ARN, or friendly name of the <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> that
--   contains the MongoDB endpoint connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:extractDocId:MongoDbSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mongoDbSettings_extractDocId</a> - Specifies the document ID. Use
--   this setting when <tt>NestingLevel</tt> is set to <tt>"none"</tt>.
--   
--   Default value is <tt>"false"</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authType:MongoDbSettings'</a>, <a>mongoDbSettings_authType</a>
--   - The authentication type you use to access the MongoDB source
--   endpoint.
--   
--   When when set to <tt>"no"</tt>, user name and password parameters are
--   not used and can be empty.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:MongoDbSettings'</a>, <a>mongoDbSettings_port</a> - The
--   port value for the MongoDB source endpoint.
newMongoDbSettings :: MongoDbSettings

-- | Provides information that defines a MySQL endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newMySQLSettings</a> smart constructor.
data MySQLSettings
MySQLSettings' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe TargetDbType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> MySQLSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>MySQLSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxFileSize:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_maxFileSize</a> - Specifies the maximum size (in KB)
--   of any .csv file used to transfer data to a MySQL-compatible database.
--   
--   Example: <tt>maxFileSize=512</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:targetDbType:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_targetDbType</a> - Specifies where to migrate source
--   tables on the target, either to a single database or multiple
--   databases.
--   
--   Example: <tt>targetDbType=MULTIPLE_DATABASES</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:MySQLSettings'</a>, <a>mySQLSettings_serverName</a>
--   - Fully qualified domain name of the endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cleanSourceMetadataOnMismatch:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_cleanSourceMetadataOnMismatch</a> - Adjusts the
--   behavior of DMS when migrating from an SQL Server source database that
--   is hosted as part of an Always On availability group cluster. If you
--   need DMS to poll all the nodes in the Always On cluster for
--   transaction backups, set this attribute to <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parallelLoadThreads:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_parallelLoadThreads</a> - Improves performance when
--   loading data into the MySQL-compatible target database. Specifies how
--   many threads to use to load the data into the MySQL-compatible target
--   database. Setting a large number of threads can have an adverse effect
--   on database performance, because a separate connection is required for
--   each thread.
--   
--   Example: <tt>parallelLoadThreads=1</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The full Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the trusted
--   entity and grants the required permissions to access the value in
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the MySQL endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:MySQLSettings'</a>, <a>mySQLSettings_username</a> -
--   Endpoint connection user name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:MySQLSettings'</a>, <a>mySQLSettings_password</a> -
--   Endpoint connection password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:eventsPollInterval:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_eventsPollInterval</a> - Specifies how often to check
--   the binary log for new changes/events when the database is idle.
--   
--   Example: <tt>eventsPollInterval=5;</tt>
--   
--   In the example, DMS checks for changes in the binary logs every five
--   seconds.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_databaseName</a> - Database name for the endpoint.
--   For a MySQL source or target endpoint, don't explicitly specify the
--   database using the <tt>DatabaseName</tt> request parameter on either
--   the <tt>CreateEndpoint</tt> or <tt>ModifyEndpoint</tt> API call.
--   Specifying <tt>DatabaseName</tt> when you create or modify a MySQL
--   endpoint replicates all the task tables to this single database. For
--   MySQL endpoints, you specify the database only when you specify the
--   schema in the table-mapping rules of the DMS task.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afterConnectScript:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_afterConnectScript</a> - Specifies a script to run
--   immediately after DMS connects to the endpoint. The migration task
--   continues running regardless if the SQL statement succeeds or fails.
--   
--   For this parameter, provide the code of the script itself, not the
--   name of a file containing the script.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full ARN, partial
--   ARN, or friendly name of the <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> that
--   contains the MySQL endpoint connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverTimezone:MySQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>mySQLSettings_serverTimezone</a> - Specifies the time zone for the
--   source MySQL database.
--   
--   Example: <tt>serverTimezone=US/Pacific;</tt>
--   
--   Note: Do not enclose time zones in single quotes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:MySQLSettings'</a>, <a>mySQLSettings_port</a> - Endpoint
--   TCP port.
newMySQLSettings :: MySQLSettings

-- | Provides information that defines an Amazon Neptune endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newNeptuneSettings</a> smart constructor.
data NeptuneSettings
NeptuneSettings' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Text -> Text -> NeptuneSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>NeptuneSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxFileSize:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_maxFileSize</a> - The maximum size in kilobytes of
--   migrated graph data stored in a .csv file before DMS bulk-loads the
--   data to the Neptune target database. The default is 1,048,576 KB. If
--   the bulk load is successful, DMS clears the bucket, ready to store the
--   next batch of migrated graph data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxRetryCount:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_maxRetryCount</a> - The number of times for DMS to
--   retry a bulk load of migrated graph data to the Neptune target
--   database before raising an error. The default is 5.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceAccessRoleArn:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_serviceAccessRoleArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the service role that you created for the Neptune target
--   endpoint. The role must allow the <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. For
--   more information, see <a>Creating an IAM Service Role for Accessing
--   Amazon Neptune as a Target</a> in the <i>Database Migration Service
--   User Guide.</i>
--   
--   <a>$sel:iamAuthEnabled:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_iamAuthEnabled</a> - If you want Identity and
--   Access Management (IAM) authorization enabled for this endpoint, set
--   this parameter to <tt>true</tt>. Then attach the appropriate IAM
--   policy document to your service role specified by
--   <tt>ServiceAccessRoleArn</tt>. The default is <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:errorRetryDuration:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_errorRetryDuration</a> - The number of milliseconds
--   for DMS to wait to retry a bulk-load of migrated graph data to the
--   Neptune target database before raising an error. The default is 250.
--   
--   <a>$sel:s3BucketName:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_s3BucketName</a> - The name of the Amazon S3 bucket
--   where DMS can temporarily store migrated graph data in .csv files
--   before bulk-loading it to the Neptune target database. DMS maps the
--   SQL source data to graph data before storing it in these .csv files.
--   
--   <a>$sel:s3BucketFolder:NeptuneSettings'</a>,
--   <a>neptuneSettings_s3BucketFolder</a> - A folder path where you want
--   DMS to store migrated graph data in the S3 bucket specified by
--   <tt>S3BucketName</tt>
newNeptuneSettings :: Text -> Text -> NeptuneSettings

-- | Provides information that defines an Oracle endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOracleSettings</a> smart constructor.
data OracleSettings
OracleSettings' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Int] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CharLengthSemantics -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> OracleSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>OracleSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:useBFile:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_useBFile</a> -
--   Set this attribute to Y to capture change data using the Binary Reader
--   utility. Set <tt>UseLogminerReader</tt> to N to set this attribute to
--   Y. To use Binary Reader with Amazon RDS for Oracle as the source, you
--   set additional attributes. For more information about using this
--   setting with Oracle Automatic Storage Management (ASM), see <a>Using
--   Oracle LogMiner or DMS Binary Reader for CDC</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:standbyDelayTime:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_standbyDelayTime</a> - Use this attribute to specify
--   a time in minutes for the delay in standby sync. If the source is an
--   Oracle Active Data Guard standby database, use this attribute to
--   specify the time lag between primary and standby databases.
--   
--   In DMS, you can create an Oracle CDC task that uses an Active Data
--   Guard standby instance as a source for replicating ongoing changes.
--   Doing this eliminates the need to connect to an active database that
--   might be in production.
--   
--   <a>$sel:failTasksOnLobTruncation:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_failTasksOnLobTruncation</a> - When set to
--   <tt>true</tt>, this attribute causes a task to fail if the actual size
--   of an LOB column is greater than the specified <tt>LobMaxSize</tt>.
--   
--   If a task is set to limited LOB mode and this option is set to
--   <tt>true</tt>, the task fails instead of truncating the LOB data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_serverName</a> - Fully qualified domain name of the
--   endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:directPathNoLog:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_directPathNoLog</a> - When set to <tt>true</tt>,
--   this attribute helps to increase the commit rate on the Oracle target
--   database by writing directly to tables and not writing a trail to
--   database logs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:extraArchivedLogDestIds:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_extraArchivedLogDestIds</a> - Specifies the IDs of
--   one more destinations for one or more archived redo logs. These IDs
--   are the values of the <tt>dest_id</tt> column in the
--   <tt>v$archived_log</tt> view. Use this setting with the
--   <tt>archivedLogDestId</tt> extra connection attribute in a
--   primary-to-single setup or a primary-to-multiple-standby setup.
--   
--   This setting is useful in a switchover when you use an Oracle Data
--   Guard database as a source. In this case, DMS needs information about
--   what destination to get archive redo logs from to read changes. DMS
--   needs this because after the switchover the previous primary is a
--   standby instance. For example, in a primary-to-single standby setup
--   you might apply the following settings.
--   
--   <pre>
--   archivedLogDestId=1; ExtraArchivedLogDestIds=[2]
--   </pre>
--   
--   In a primary-to-multiple-standby setup, you might apply the following
--   settings.
--   
--   <pre>
--   archivedLogDestId=1; ExtraArchivedLogDestIds=[2,3,4]
--   </pre>
--   
--   Although DMS supports the use of the Oracle <tt>RESETLOGS</tt> option
--   to open the database, never use <tt>RESETLOGS</tt> unless it's
--   necessary. For more information about <tt>RESETLOGS</tt>, see <a>RMAN
--   Data Repair Concepts</a> in the <i>Oracle Database Backup and Recovery
--   User's Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityDbEncryptionName:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_securityDbEncryptionName</a> - For an Oracle source
--   endpoint, the name of a key used for the transparent data encryption
--   (TDE) of the columns and tablespaces in an Oracle source database that
--   is encrypted using TDE. The key value is the value of the
--   <tt>SecurityDbEncryption</tt> setting. For more information on setting
--   the key name value of <tt>SecurityDbEncryptionName</tt>, see the
--   information and example for setting the
--   <tt>securityDbEncryptionName</tt> extra connection attribute in
--   <a>Supported encryption methods for using Oracle as a source for
--   DMS</a> in the <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:oraclePathPrefix:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_oraclePathPrefix</a> - Set this string attribute to
--   the required value in order to use the Binary Reader to capture change
--   data for an Amazon RDS for Oracle as the source. This value specifies
--   the default Oracle root used to access the redo logs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The full Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the trusted
--   entity and grants the required permissions to access the value in
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the Oracle endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useDirectPathFullLoad:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_useDirectPathFullLoad</a> - Set this attribute to Y
--   to have DMS use a direct path full load. Specify this value to use the
--   direct path protocol in the Oracle Call Interface (OCI). By using this
--   OCI protocol, you can bulk-load Oracle target tables during a full
--   load.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_username</a> -
--   Endpoint connection user name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowSelectNestedTables:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_allowSelectNestedTables</a> - Set this attribute to
--   <tt>true</tt> to enable replication of Oracle tables containing
--   columns that are nested tables or defined types.
--   
--   <a>$sel:readAheadBlocks:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_readAheadBlocks</a> - Set this attribute to change
--   the number of read-ahead blocks that DMS configures to perform a
--   change data capture (CDC) load using Oracle Automatic Storage
--   Management (ASM). You can specify an integer value between 1000 (the
--   default) and 200,000 (the maximum).
--   
--   <a>$sel:archivedLogDestId:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_archivedLogDestId</a> - Specifies the ID of the
--   destination for the archived redo logs. This value should be the same
--   as a number in the dest_id column of the v$archived_log view. If you
--   work with an additional redo log destination, use the
--   <tt>AdditionalArchivedLogDestId</tt> option to specify the additional
--   destination ID. Doing this improves performance by ensuring that the
--   correct logs are accessed from the outset.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replacePathPrefix:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_replacePathPrefix</a> - Set this attribute to true
--   in order to use the Binary Reader to capture change data for an Amazon
--   RDS for Oracle as the source. This setting tells DMS instance to
--   replace the default Oracle root with the specified
--   <tt>usePathPrefix</tt> setting to access the redo logs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:accessAlternateDirectly:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_accessAlternateDirectly</a> - Set this attribute to
--   <tt>false</tt> in order to use the Binary Reader to capture change
--   data for an Amazon RDS for Oracle as the source. This tells the DMS
--   instance to not access redo logs through any specified path prefix
--   replacement using direct file access.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerOracleAsmSecretId:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_secretsManagerOracleAsmSecretId</a> - Required only
--   if your Oracle endpoint uses Advanced Storage Manager (ASM). The full
--   ARN, partial ARN, or friendly name of the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecret</tt> that contains the Oracle ASM
--   connection details for the Oracle endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:securityDbEncryption:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_securityDbEncryption</a> - For an Oracle source
--   endpoint, the transparent data encryption (TDE) password required by
--   AWM DMS to access Oracle redo logs encrypted by TDE using Binary
--   Reader. It is also the <tt> TDE_Password </tt> part of the
--   comma-separated value you set to the <tt>Password</tt> request
--   parameter when you create the endpoint. The
--   <tt>SecurityDbEncryptian</tt> setting is related to this
--   <tt>SecurityDbEncryptionName</tt> setting. For more information, see
--   <a>Supported encryption methods for using Oracle as a source for
--   DMS</a> in the <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useLogminerReader:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_useLogminerReader</a> - Set this attribute to Y to
--   capture change data using the Oracle LogMiner utility (the default).
--   Set this attribute to N if you want to access the redo logs as a
--   binary file. When you set <tt>UseLogminerReader</tt> to N, also set
--   <tt>UseBfile</tt> to Y. For more information on this setting and using
--   Oracle ASM, see <a>Using Oracle LogMiner or DMS Binary Reader for
--   CDC</a> in the <i>DMS User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:readTableSpaceName:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_readTableSpaceName</a> - When set to <tt>true</tt>,
--   this attribute supports tablespace replication.
--   
--   <a>$sel:retryInterval:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_retryInterval</a> - Specifies the number of seconds
--   that the system waits before resending a query.
--   
--   Example: <tt>retryInterval=6;</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_password</a> -
--   Endpoint connection password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:spatialDataOptionToGeoJsonFunctionName:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_spatialDataOptionToGeoJsonFunctionName</a> - Use
--   this attribute to convert <tt>SDO_GEOMETRY</tt> to <tt>GEOJSON</tt>
--   format. By default, DMS calls the <tt>SDO2GEOJSON</tt> custom function
--   if present and accessible. Or you can create your own custom function
--   that mimics the operation of <tt>SDOGEOJSON</tt> and set
--   <tt>SpatialDataOptionToGeoJsonFunctionName</tt> to call it instead.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_databaseName</a> - Database name for the endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:addSupplementalLogging:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_addSupplementalLogging</a> - Set this attribute to
--   set up table-level supplemental logging for the Oracle database. This
--   attribute enables PRIMARY KEY supplemental logging on all tables
--   selected for a migration task.
--   
--   If you use this option, you still need to enable database-level
--   supplemental logging.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerOracleAsmAccessRoleArn:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_secretsManagerOracleAsmAccessRoleArn</a> - Required
--   only if your Oracle endpoint uses Advanced Storage Manager (ASM). The
--   full ARN of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the trusted entity and
--   grants the required permissions to access the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecret</tt>. This
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecret</tt> has the secret value that
--   allows access to the Oracle ASM of the endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify
--   clear-text values for <tt>AsmUserName</tt>, <tt>AsmPassword</tt>, and
--   <tt>AsmServerName</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information
--   on creating this <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerOracleAsmSecretId</tt> required to access it, see
--   <a>Using secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in
--   the <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:asmServer:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_asmServer</a>
--   - For an Oracle source endpoint, your ASM server address. You can set
--   this value from the <tt>asm_server</tt> value. You set
--   <tt>asm_server</tt> as part of the extra connection attribute string
--   to access an Oracle server with Binary Reader that uses ASM. For more
--   information, see <a>Configuration for change data capture (CDC) on an
--   Oracle source database</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:charLengthSemantics:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_charLengthSemantics</a> - Specifies whether the
--   length of a character column is in bytes or in characters. To indicate
--   that the character column length is in characters, set this attribute
--   to <tt>CHAR</tt>. Otherwise, the character column length is in bytes.
--   
--   Example: <tt>charLengthSemantics=CHAR;</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:archivedLogsOnly:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_archivedLogsOnly</a> - When this field is set to
--   <tt>Y</tt>, DMS only accesses the archived redo logs. If the archived
--   redo logs are stored on Oracle ASM only, the DMS user account needs to
--   be granted ASM privileges.
--   
--   <a>$sel:directPathParallelLoad:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_directPathParallelLoad</a> - When set to
--   <tt>true</tt>, this attribute specifies a parallel load when
--   <tt>useDirectPathFullLoad</tt> is set to <tt>Y</tt>. This attribute
--   also only applies when you use the DMS parallel load feature. Note
--   that the target table cannot have any constraints or indexes.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full ARN, partial
--   ARN, or friendly name of the <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> that
--   contains the Oracle endpoint connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:additionalArchivedLogDestId:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_additionalArchivedLogDestId</a> - Set this attribute
--   with <tt>ArchivedLogDestId</tt> in a primary/ standby setup. This
--   attribute is useful in the case of a switchover. In this case, DMS
--   needs to know which destination to get archive redo logs from to read
--   changes. This need arises because the previous primary instance is now
--   a standby instance after switchover.
--   
--   Although DMS supports the use of the Oracle <tt>RESETLOGS</tt> option
--   to open the database, never use <tt>RESETLOGS</tt> unless necessary.
--   For additional information about <tt>RESETLOGS</tt>, see <a>RMAN Data
--   Repair Concepts</a> in the <i>Oracle Database Backup and Recovery
--   User's Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:asmPassword:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_asmPassword</a> - For an Oracle source endpoint,
--   your Oracle Automatic Storage Management (ASM) password. You can set
--   this value from the <tt> asm_user_password </tt> value. You set this
--   value as part of the comma-separated value that you set to the
--   <tt>Password</tt> request parameter when you create the endpoint to
--   access transaction logs using Binary Reader. For more information, see
--   <a>Configuration for change data capture (CDC) on an Oracle source
--   database</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enableHomogenousTablespace:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_enableHomogenousTablespace</a> - Set this attribute
--   to enable homogenous tablespace replication and create existing tables
--   or indexes under the same tablespace on the target.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parallelAsmReadThreads:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_parallelAsmReadThreads</a> - Set this attribute to
--   change the number of threads that DMS configures to perform a change
--   data capture (CDC) load using Oracle Automatic Storage Management
--   (ASM). You can specify an integer value between 2 (the default) and 8
--   (the maximum). Use this attribute together with the
--   <tt>readAheadBlocks</tt> attribute.
--   
--   <a>$sel:numberDatatypeScale:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_numberDatatypeScale</a> - Specifies the number
--   scale. You can select a scale up to 38, or you can select FLOAT. By
--   default, the NUMBER data type is converted to precision 38, scale 10.
--   
--   Example: <tt>numberDataTypeScale=12</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:usePathPrefix:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_usePathPrefix</a> - Set this string attribute to the
--   required value in order to use the Binary Reader to capture change
--   data for an Amazon RDS for Oracle as the source. This value specifies
--   the path prefix used to replace the default Oracle root to access the
--   redo logs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:asmUser:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_asmUser</a> -
--   For an Oracle source endpoint, your ASM user name. You can set this
--   value from the <tt>asm_user</tt> value. You set <tt>asm_user</tt> as
--   part of the extra connection attribute string to access an Oracle
--   server with Binary Reader that uses ASM. For more information, see
--   <a>Configuration for change data capture (CDC) on an Oracle source
--   database</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:useAlternateFolderForOnline:OracleSettings'</a>,
--   <a>oracleSettings_useAlternateFolderForOnline</a> - Set this attribute
--   to <tt>true</tt> in order to use the Binary Reader to capture change
--   data for an Amazon RDS for Oracle as the source. This tells the DMS
--   instance to use any specified prefix replacement to access all online
--   redo logs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:OracleSettings'</a>, <a>oracleSettings_port</a> -
--   Endpoint TCP port.
newOracleSettings :: OracleSettings

-- | In response to the <tt>DescribeOrderableReplicationInstances</tt>
--   operation, this object describes an available replication instance.
--   This description includes the replication instance's type, engine
--   version, and allocated storage.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newOrderableReplicationInstance</a> smart constructor.
data OrderableReplicationInstance
OrderableReplicationInstance' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe ReleaseStatusValues -> Maybe Int -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> OrderableReplicationInstance

-- | Create a value of <a>OrderableReplicationInstance</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_engineVersion</a> - The version of the
--   replication engine.
--   
--   <a>$sel:minAllocatedStorage:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_minAllocatedStorage</a> - The minimum
--   amount of storage (in gigabytes) that can be allocated for the
--   replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:releaseStatus:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_releaseStatus</a> - The value returned
--   when the specified <tt>EngineVersion</tt> of the replication instance
--   is in Beta or test mode. This indicates some features might not work
--   as expected.
--   
--   DMS supports the <tt>ReleaseStatus</tt> parameter in versions 3.1.4
--   and later.
--   
--   <a>$sel:includedAllocatedStorage:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_includedAllocatedStorage</a> - The
--   amount of storage (in gigabytes) that is allocated for the replication
--   instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZones:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_availabilityZones</a> - List of
--   Availability Zones for this replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxAllocatedStorage:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_maxAllocatedStorage</a> - The minimum
--   amount of storage (in gigabytes) that can be allocated for the
--   replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstanceClass:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_replicationInstanceClass</a> - The
--   compute and memory capacity of the replication instance as defined for
--   the specified replication instance class. For example to specify the
--   instance class dms.c4.large, set this parameter to
--   <tt>"dms.c4.large"</tt>.
--   
--   For more information on the settings and capacities for the available
--   replication instance classes, see <a>Selecting the right DMS
--   replication instance for your migration</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:defaultAllocatedStorage:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_defaultAllocatedStorage</a> - The
--   default amount of storage (in gigabytes) that is allocated for the
--   replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:storageType:OrderableReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>orderableReplicationInstance_storageType</a> - The type of storage
--   used by the replication instance.
newOrderableReplicationInstance :: OrderableReplicationInstance

-- | Describes a maintenance action pending for an DMS resource, including
--   when and how it will be applied. This data type is a response element
--   to the <tt>DescribePendingMaintenanceActions</tt> operation.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPendingMaintenanceAction</a> smart constructor.
data PendingMaintenanceAction
PendingMaintenanceAction' :: Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> PendingMaintenanceAction

-- | Create a value of <a>PendingMaintenanceAction</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoAppliedAfterDate:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_autoAppliedAfterDate</a> - The date of the
--   maintenance window when the action is to be applied. The maintenance
--   action is applied to the resource during its first maintenance window
--   after this date. If this date is specified, any
--   <tt>next-maintenance</tt> opt-in requests are ignored.
--   
--   <a>$sel:action:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_action</a> - The type of pending
--   maintenance action that is available for the resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:optInStatus:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_optInStatus</a> - The type of opt-in
--   request that has been received for the resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:description:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_description</a> - A description providing
--   more detail about the maintenance action.
--   
--   <a>$sel:forcedApplyDate:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_forcedApplyDate</a> - The date when the
--   maintenance action will be automatically applied. The maintenance
--   action is applied to the resource on this date regardless of the
--   maintenance window for the resource. If this date is specified, any
--   <tt>immediate</tt> opt-in requests are ignored.
--   
--   <a>$sel:currentApplyDate:PendingMaintenanceAction'</a>,
--   <a>pendingMaintenanceAction_currentApplyDate</a> - The effective date
--   when the pending maintenance action will be applied to the resource.
--   This date takes into account opt-in requests received from the
--   <tt>ApplyPendingMaintenanceAction</tt> API operation, and also the
--   <tt>AutoAppliedAfterDate</tt> and <tt>ForcedApplyDate</tt> parameter
--   values. This value is blank if an opt-in request has not been received
--   and nothing has been specified for <tt>AutoAppliedAfterDate</tt> or
--   <tt>ForcedApplyDate</tt>.
newPendingMaintenanceAction :: PendingMaintenanceAction

-- | Provides information that defines a PostgreSQL endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPostgreSQLSettings</a> smart constructor.
data PostgreSQLSettings
PostgreSQLSettings' :: Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe PluginNameValue -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> PostgreSQLSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>PostgreSQLSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:executeTimeout:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_executeTimeout</a> - Sets the client statement
--   timeout for the PostgreSQL instance, in seconds. The default value is
--   60 seconds.
--   
--   Example: <tt>executeTimeout=100;</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxFileSize:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_maxFileSize</a> - Specifies the maximum size (in
--   KB) of any .csv file used to transfer data to PostgreSQL.
--   
--   Example: <tt>maxFileSize=512</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:failTasksOnLobTruncation:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_failTasksOnLobTruncation</a> - When set to
--   <tt>true</tt>, this value causes a task to fail if the actual size of
--   a LOB column is greater than the specified <tt>LobMaxSize</tt>.
--   
--   If task is set to Limited LOB mode and this option is set to true, the
--   task fails instead of truncating the LOB data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_serverName</a> - Fully qualified domain name of
--   the endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ddlArtifactsSchema:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_ddlArtifactsSchema</a> - The schema in which the
--   operational DDL database artifacts are created.
--   
--   Example: <tt>ddlArtifactsSchema=xyzddlschema;</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:slotName:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_slotName</a> - Sets the name of a previously
--   created logical replication slot for a change data capture (CDC) load
--   of the PostgreSQL source instance.
--   
--   When used with the <tt>CdcStartPosition</tt> request parameter for the
--   DMS API , this attribute also makes it possible to use native CDC
--   start points. DMS verifies that the specified logical replication slot
--   exists before starting the CDC load task. It also verifies that the
--   task was created with a valid setting of <tt>CdcStartPosition</tt>. If
--   the specified slot doesn't exist or the task doesn't have a valid
--   <tt>CdcStartPosition</tt> setting, DMS raises an error.
--   
--   For more information about setting the <tt>CdcStartPosition</tt>
--   request parameter, see <a>Determining a CDC native start point</a> in
--   the <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>. For more information
--   about using <tt>CdcStartPosition</tt>, see
--   <a>CreateReplicationTask</a>, <a>StartReplicationTask</a>, and
--   <a>ModifyReplicationTask</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The full
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the
--   trusted entity and grants the required permissions to access the value
--   in <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the PostgreSQL endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_username</a> - Endpoint connection user name.
--   
--   <a>$sel:heartbeatFrequency:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_heartbeatFrequency</a> - Sets the WAL heartbeat
--   frequency (in minutes).
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_password</a> - Endpoint connection password.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_databaseName</a> - Database name for the
--   endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afterConnectScript:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_afterConnectScript</a> - For use with change
--   data capture (CDC) only, this attribute has DMS bypass foreign keys
--   and user triggers to reduce the time it takes to bulk load data.
--   
--   Example: <tt>afterConnectScript=SET
--   session_replication_role='replica'</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full ARN,
--   partial ARN, or friendly name of the <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>
--   that contains the PostgreSQL endpoint connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:captureDdls:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_captureDdls</a> - To capture DDL events, DMS
--   creates various artifacts in the PostgreSQL database when the task
--   starts. You can later remove these artifacts.
--   
--   If this value is set to <tt>N</tt>, you don't have to create tables or
--   triggers on the source database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:pluginName:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_pluginName</a> - Specifies the plugin to use to
--   create a replication slot.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>, <a>postgreSQLSettings_port</a> -
--   Endpoint TCP port.
--   
--   <a>$sel:heartbeatSchema:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_heartbeatSchema</a> - Sets the schema in which
--   the heartbeat artifacts are created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:heartbeatEnable:PostgreSQLSettings'</a>,
--   <a>postgreSQLSettings_heartbeatEnable</a> - The write-ahead log (WAL)
--   heartbeat feature mimics a dummy transaction. By doing this, it
--   prevents idle logical replication slots from holding onto old WAL
--   logs, which can result in storage full situations on the source. This
--   heartbeat keeps <tt>restart_lsn</tt> moving and prevents storage full
--   scenarios.
newPostgreSQLSettings :: PostgreSQLSettings

-- | Provides information that defines a Redis target endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRedisSettings</a> smart constructor.
data RedisSettings
RedisSettings' :: Maybe SslSecurityProtocolValue -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe RedisAuthTypeValue -> Text -> Int -> RedisSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>RedisSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslSecurityProtocol:RedisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redisSettings_sslSecurityProtocol</a> - The connection to a Redis
--   target endpoint using Transport Layer Security (TLS). Valid values
--   include <tt>plaintext</tt> and <tt>ssl-encryption</tt>. The default is
--   <tt>ssl-encryption</tt>. The <tt>ssl-encryption</tt> option makes an
--   encrypted connection. Optionally, you can identify an Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) for an SSL certificate authority (CA) using the
--   <tt>SslCaCertificateArn </tt>setting. If an ARN isn't given for a CA,
--   DMS uses the Amazon root CA.
--   
--   The <tt>plaintext</tt> option doesn't provide Transport Layer Security
--   (TLS) encryption for traffic between endpoint and database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authUserName:RedisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redisSettings_authUserName</a> - The user name provided with the
--   <tt>auth-role</tt> option of the <tt>AuthType</tt> setting for a Redis
--   target endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sslCaCertificateArn:RedisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redisSettings_sslCaCertificateArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) for the certificate authority (CA) that DMS uses to connect to
--   your Redis target endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authPassword:RedisSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redisSettings_authPassword</a> - The password provided with the
--   <tt>auth-role</tt> and <tt>auth-token</tt> options of the
--   <tt>AuthType</tt> setting for a Redis target endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:authType:RedisSettings'</a>, <a>redisSettings_authType</a> -
--   The type of authentication to perform when connecting to a Redis
--   target. Options include <tt>none</tt>, <tt>auth-token</tt>, and
--   <tt>auth-role</tt>. The <tt>auth-token</tt> option requires an
--   <tt>AuthPassword</tt> value to be provided. The <tt>auth-role</tt>
--   option requires <tt>AuthUserName</tt> and <tt>AuthPassword</tt> values
--   to be provided.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:RedisSettings'</a>, <a>redisSettings_serverName</a>
--   - Fully qualified domain name of the endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:RedisSettings'</a>, <a>redisSettings_port</a> -
--   Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) port for the endpoint.
newRedisSettings :: Text -> Int -> RedisSettings

-- | Provides information that defines an Amazon Redshift endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRedshiftSettings</a> smart constructor.
data RedshiftSettings
RedshiftSettings' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe EncryptionModeValue -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe (Sensitive Text) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Int -> RedshiftSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>RedshiftSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:emptyAsNull:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_emptyAsNull</a> - A value that specifies whether
--   DMS should migrate empty CHAR and VARCHAR fields as NULL. A value of
--   <tt>true</tt> sets empty CHAR and VARCHAR fields to null. The default
--   is <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:caseSensitiveNames:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_caseSensitiveNames</a> - If Amazon Redshift is
--   configured to support case sensitive schema names, set
--   <tt>CaseSensitiveNames</tt> to <tt>true</tt>. The default is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxFileSize:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_maxFileSize</a> - The maximum size (in KB) of any
--   .csv file used to load data on an S3 bucket and transfer data to
--   Amazon Redshift. It defaults to 1048576KB (1 GB).
--   
--   <a>$sel:replaceChars:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_replaceChars</a> - A value that specifies to
--   replaces the invalid characters specified in
--   <tt>ReplaceInvalidChars</tt>, substituting the specified characters
--   instead. The default is <tt>"?"</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverName:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_serverName</a> - The name of the Amazon Redshift
--   cluster you are using.
--   
--   <a>$sel:connectionTimeout:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_connectionTimeout</a> - A value that sets the
--   amount of time to wait (in milliseconds) before timing out, beginning
--   from when you initially establish a connection.
--   
--   <a>$sel:loadTimeout:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_loadTimeout</a> - The amount of time to wait (in
--   milliseconds) before timing out of operations performed by DMS on a
--   Redshift cluster, such as Redshift COPY, INSERT, DELETE, and UPDATE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serviceAccessRoleArn:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_serviceAccessRoleArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the IAM role that has access to the Amazon Redshift
--   service. The role must allow the <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action.
--   
--   <a>$sel:explicitIds:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_explicitIds</a> - This setting is only valid for a
--   full-load migration task. Set <tt>ExplicitIds</tt> to <tt>true</tt> to
--   have tables with <tt>IDENTITY</tt> columns override their
--   auto-generated values with explicit values loaded from the source data
--   files used to populate the tables. The default is <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketFolder:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_bucketFolder</a> - An S3 folder where the
--   comma-separated-value (.csv) files are stored before being uploaded to
--   the target Redshift cluster.
--   
--   For full load mode, DMS converts source records into .csv files and
--   loads them to the <i>BucketFolder/TableID</i> path. DMS uses the
--   Redshift <tt>COPY</tt> command to upload the .csv files to the target
--   table. The files are deleted once the <tt>COPY</tt> operation has
--   finished. For more information, see <a>COPY</a> in the <i>Amazon
--   Redshift Database Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   For change-data-capture (CDC) mode, DMS creates a <i>NetChanges</i>
--   table, and loads the .csv files to this
--   <i>BucketFolder/NetChangesTableID</i> path.
--   
--   <a>$sel:truncateColumns:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_truncateColumns</a> - A value that specifies to
--   truncate data in columns to the appropriate number of characters, so
--   that the data fits in the column. This parameter applies only to
--   columns with a VARCHAR or CHAR data type, and rows with a size of 4 MB
--   or less. Choose <tt>true</tt> to truncate data. The default is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerAccessRoleArn:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_secretsManagerAccessRoleArn</a> - The full Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the IAM role that specifies DMS as the trusted
--   entity and grants the required permissions to access the value in
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt>. The role must allow the
--   <tt>iam:PassRole</tt> action. <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> has the
--   value of the Amazon Web Services Secrets Manager secret that allows
--   access to the Amazon Redshift endpoint.
--   
--   You can specify one of two sets of values for these permissions. You
--   can specify the values for this setting and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt>. Or you can specify clear-text values
--   for <tt>UserName</tt>, <tt>Password</tt>, <tt>ServerName</tt>, and
--   <tt>Port</tt>. You can't specify both. For more information on
--   creating this <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> and the
--   <tt>SecretsManagerAccessRoleArn</tt> and
--   <tt>SecretsManagerSecretId</tt> required to access it, see <a>Using
--   secrets to access Database Migration Service resources</a> in the
--   <i>Database Migration Service User Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replaceInvalidChars:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_replaceInvalidChars</a> - A list of characters
--   that you want to replace. Use with <tt>ReplaceChars</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:username:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_username</a> - An Amazon Redshift user name for a
--   registered user.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bucketName:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_bucketName</a> - The name of the intermediate S3
--   bucket used to store .csv files before uploading data to Redshift.
--   
--   <a>$sel:encryptionMode:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_encryptionMode</a> - The type of server-side
--   encryption that you want to use for your data. This encryption type is
--   part of the endpoint settings or the extra connections attributes for
--   Amazon S3. You can choose either <tt>SSE_S3</tt> (the default) or
--   <tt>SSE_KMS</tt>.
--   
--   For the <tt>ModifyEndpoint</tt> operation, you can change the existing
--   value of the <tt>EncryptionMode</tt> parameter from <tt>SSE_KMS</tt>
--   to <tt>SSE_S3</tt>. But you canâ€™t change the existing value from
--   <tt>SSE_S3</tt> to <tt>SSE_KMS</tt>.
--   
--   To use <tt>SSE_S3</tt>, create an Identity and Access Management (IAM)
--   role with a policy that allows <tt>"arn:aws:s3:::*"</tt> to use the
--   following actions: <tt>"s3:PutObject", "s3:ListBucket"</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:dateFormat:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_dateFormat</a> - The date format that you are
--   using. Valid values are <tt>auto</tt> (case-sensitive), your date
--   format string enclosed in quotes, or NULL. If this parameter is left
--   unset (NULL), it defaults to a format of 'YYYY-MM-DD'. Using
--   <tt>auto</tt> recognizes most strings, even some that aren't supported
--   when you use a date format string.
--   
--   If your date and time values use formats different from each other,
--   set this to <tt>auto</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:removeQuotes:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_removeQuotes</a> - A value that specifies to
--   remove surrounding quotation marks from strings in the incoming data.
--   All characters within the quotation marks, including delimiters, are
--   retained. Choose <tt>true</tt> to remove quotation marks. The default
--   is <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:password:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_password</a> - The password for the user named in
--   the <tt>username</tt> property.
--   
--   <a>$sel:databaseName:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_databaseName</a> - The name of the Amazon Redshift
--   data warehouse (service) that you are working with.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceptAnyDate:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_acceptAnyDate</a> - A value that indicates to
--   allow any date format, including invalid formats such as 00/00/00
--   00:00:00, to be loaded without generating an error. You can choose
--   <tt>true</tt> or <tt>false</tt> (the default).
--   
--   This parameter applies only to TIMESTAMP and DATE columns. Always use
--   ACCEPTANYDATE with the DATEFORMAT parameter. If the date format for
--   the data doesn't match the DATEFORMAT specification, Amazon Redshift
--   inserts a NULL value into that field.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afterConnectScript:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_afterConnectScript</a> - Code to run after
--   connecting. This parameter should contain the code itself, not the
--   name of a file containing the code.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secretsManagerSecretId:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_secretsManagerSecretId</a> - The full ARN, partial
--   ARN, or friendly name of the <tt>SecretsManagerSecret</tt> that
--   contains the Amazon Redshift endpoint connection details.
--   
--   <a>$sel:writeBufferSize:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_writeBufferSize</a> - The size (in KB) of the
--   in-memory file write buffer used when generating .csv files on the
--   local disk at the DMS replication instance. The default value is 1000
--   (buffer size is 1000KB).
--   
--   <a>$sel:compUpdate:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_compUpdate</a> - If you set <tt>CompUpdate</tt> to
--   <tt>true</tt> Amazon Redshift applies automatic compression if the
--   table is empty. This applies even if the table columns already have
--   encodings other than <tt>RAW</tt>. If you set <tt>CompUpdate</tt> to
--   <tt>false</tt>, automatic compression is disabled and existing column
--   encodings aren't changed. The default is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trimBlanks:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_trimBlanks</a> - A value that specifies to remove
--   the trailing white space characters from a VARCHAR string. This
--   parameter applies only to columns with a VARCHAR data type. Choose
--   <tt>true</tt> to remove unneeded white space. The default is
--   <tt>false</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timeFormat:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_timeFormat</a> - The time format that you want to
--   use. Valid values are <tt>auto</tt> (case-sensitive),
--   <tt>'timeformat_string'</tt>, <tt>'epochsecs'</tt>, or
--   <tt>'epochmillisecs'</tt>. It defaults to 10. Using <tt>auto</tt>
--   recognizes most strings, even some that aren't supported when you use
--   a time format string.
--   
--   If your date and time values use formats different from each other,
--   set this parameter to <tt>auto</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:serverSideEncryptionKmsKeyId:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_serverSideEncryptionKmsKeyId</a> - The KMS key ID.
--   If you are using <tt>SSE_KMS</tt> for the <tt>EncryptionMode</tt>,
--   provide this key ID. The key that you use needs an attached policy
--   that enables IAM user permissions and allows use of the key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:RedshiftSettings'</a>, <a>redshiftSettings_port</a> - The
--   port number for Amazon Redshift. The default value is 5439.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fileTransferUploadStreams:RedshiftSettings'</a>,
--   <a>redshiftSettings_fileTransferUploadStreams</a> - The number of
--   threads used to upload a single file. This parameter accepts a value
--   from 1 through 64. It defaults to 10.
--   
--   The number of parallel streams used to upload a single .csv file to an
--   S3 bucket using S3 Multipart Upload. For more information, see
--   <a>Multipart upload overview</a>.
--   
--   <tt>FileTransferUploadStreams</tt> accepts a value from 1 through 64.
--   It defaults to 10.
newRedshiftSettings :: RedshiftSettings

-- | Provides information that defines a replication instance.
--

data ReplicationInstance
ReplicationInstance' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe ReplicationSubnetGroup -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [VpcSecurityGroupMembership] -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Int -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe ReplicationPendingModifiedValues -> ReplicationInstance

--   omitted.
--

--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:engineVersion:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_engineVersion</a> - The engine version number
--   of the replication instance.
--   
--   If an engine version number is not specified when a replication
--   instance is created, the default is the latest engine version
--   available.
--   
--   When modifying a major engine version of an instance, also set
--   <tt>AllowMajorVersionUpgrade</tt> to <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:publiclyAccessible:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_publiclyAccessible</a> - Specifies the
--   accessibility options for the replication instance. A value of
--   <tt>true</tt> represents an instance with a public IP address. A value
--   of <tt>false</tt> represents an instance with a private IP address.
--   The default value is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:autoMinorVersionUpgrade:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_autoMinorVersionUpgrade</a> - Boolean value
--   indicating if minor version upgrades will be automatically applied to
--   the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstancePublicIpAddresses:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstancePublicIpAddresses</a> - One
--   or more public IP addresses for the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationSubnetGroup:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationSubnetGroup</a> - The subnet group
--   for the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:instanceCreateTime:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_instanceCreateTime</a> - The time the
--   replication instance was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:freeUntil:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_freeUntil</a> - The expiration date of the free
--   replication instance that is part of the Free DMS program.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstanceStatus:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstanceStatus</a> - The status of
--   the replication instance. The possible return values include:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><pre>"available"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"creating"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"deleted"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"deleting"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"failed"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"modifying"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"upgrading"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"rebooting"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"resetting-master-credentials"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"storage-full"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"incompatible-credentials"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"incompatible-network"</pre></li>
--   <li><pre>"maintenance"</pre></li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstancePrivateIpAddresses:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstancePrivateIpAddresses</a> - One
--   or more private IP addresses for the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:preferredMaintenanceWindow:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_preferredMaintenanceWindow</a> - The
--   maintenance window times for the replication instance. Any pending
--   upgrades to the replication instance are performed during this time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstancePrivateIpAddress:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstancePrivateIpAddress</a> - The
--   private IP address of the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:kmsKeyId:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_kmsKeyId</a> - An KMS key identifier that is
--   used to encrypt the data on the replication instance.
--   
--   If you don't specify a value for the <tt>KmsKeyId</tt> parameter, then
--   DMS uses your default encryption key.
--   
--   KMS creates the default encryption key for your Amazon Web Services
--   account. Your Amazon Web Services account has a different default
--   encryption key for each Amazon Web Services Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:availabilityZone:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_availabilityZone</a> - The Availability Zone
--   for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:vpcSecurityGroups:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_vpcSecurityGroups</a> - The VPC security group
--   for the instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:multiAZ:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_multiAZ</a> - Specifies whether the replication
--   instance is a Multi-AZ deployment. You can't set the
--   <tt>AvailabilityZone</tt> parameter if the Multi-AZ parameter is set
--   to <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:secondaryAvailabilityZone:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_secondaryAvailabilityZone</a> - The
--   Availability Zone of the standby replication instance in a Multi-AZ
--   deployment.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstanceArn:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstanceArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allocatedStorage:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_allocatedStorage</a> - The amount of storage
--   (in gigabytes) that is allocated for the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsNameServers:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_dnsNameServers</a> - The DNS name servers
--   supported for the replication instance to access your on-premise
--   source or target database.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstancePublicIpAddress:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstancePublicIpAddress</a> - The
--   public IP address of the replication instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstanceClass:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstanceClass</a> - The compute and
--   memory capacity of the replication instance as defined for the
--   specified replication instance class. It is a required parameter,
--   although a default value is pre-selected in the DMS console.
--   
--   For more information on the settings and capacities for the available
--   replication instance classes, see <a>Selecting the right DMS
--   replication instance for your migration</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:replicationInstanceIdentifier:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_replicationInstanceIdentifier</a> - The
--   replication instance identifier is a required parameter. This
--   parameter is stored as a lowercase string.
--   
--   Constraints:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Must contain 1-63 alphanumeric characters or hyphens.</li>
--   <li>First character must be a letter.</li>
--   <li>Cannot end with a hyphen or contain two consecutive hyphens.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Example: <tt>myrepinstance</tt>
--   
--   <a>$sel:pendingModifiedValues:ReplicationInstance'</a>,
--   <a>replicationInstance_pendingModifiedValues</a> - The pending
--   modification values.
newReplicationInstance :: ReplicationInstance
